discussion.content: It executes successfully and all the rows are updated

Answer is B because the value is Bookkeeper ( Senior ) is more than 18 characters as specified

choices.D: It gives an error and all the data manipulation language (DML) statements are rolled back.
choices.B: It gives an error but saves the inserted rows and the update to the first row.
choices.C: It gives an error but saves the inserted rows; however, no rows are updated.
choices.A: It executes successfully and all the rows are updated.

choices.E: It can be a before or an after trigger.

discussion.content: I would argue that the E is also correct - theoretically you can check how much rows is going to be deleted and calculate how much will remain before delete is executed, it's just less convenient that way.

questions.question_text:
You want to create a trigger that fires whenever rows are deleted from the customer table and that displays the number of rows remaining in the table.
Which two statements are correct about the trigger to be created for the above requirement? (Choose two.)

choices.A: It executes successfully but no error messages get recorded in the DEBUG_OUTPUT table
choices.D: It gives an error because procedures containing PRAGMA AUTONOMOUS_TRANSACTION cannot be called from the exception section.
choices.B: It executes successfully and any error messages get recorded in the DEBUG_OUTPUT table.
choices.C: It gives an error because PRAGMA AUTONOMOUS_TRANSACTION can be used only in packaged procedures.

questions.answer_description: In this case, the debug output will only occur if there is an exception.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
"A" is the correct answer!

Could be B as well.
BEFORE trigger can raise an exception in which case the debugging method will be called.

The answer is correct. Explanation : Till the time a number value is passed to the procedure, it will not error out as if the row gets deleted it executes successfully. Even if the row is not deleted it is the case of '0 rows' deleted and still the procedure will execute successfully.

LINE/COL ERROR
——– —————————————————————–
4/11 PLS-00323: subprogram or cursor ‘PROC2’ is declared in a package
specification and must be defined in the package body

Yes, A is the correct answer.
Explanation - It is not a mandate to declare all the procedures/functions inside a package body in declarative section too. 
Whatever is declared in declarative section of a package declaration becomes public. i.e. accessible outside package also using <<package_name.procedure_name>>.
However, the procedures/functions declared in the package specification/declarative part should be defined in package body otherwise it gives error procedure body missing.

comments.content: i think only A, because in Package body we can write hidden subprograms, without specifying them in PACKAGE SPECIFICATION.

choices.B: The PROC3 procedure should be declared in the package specification.
choices.A: The PROC2 procedure code should be defined in the package body.
choices.C: The PROC3 procedure header should be declared at the beginning of the package body.
choices.D: The variable x must be declared in the package body and removed from the specification,

choices.C: It gives an error in line 6.
choices.B: It gives an error in line 4.
choices.A: It gives an error in line 3.
choices.D: It executes successfully and displays the output.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is correct, simply try it.
I ran it in 18c and it seems to work successfully. I guess the rules have changed since 11g.

B is correct. Line 3 is variable is constant and it's initialized. The line 4 variable is declared to be the same type as the variable in line 3, thus inheriting the properties of the line 3 variable. Therefore the variable in line 4 needs to be initialized.
